description: Primes in A092845 (decimal expansion of pi written backwards).
comments: Next term is probably A092845(711), a 712-digit probable prime (Baillie-Pomerance-Selfridge-Wagstaff test, cf. PARI/gp documentation) beginning 2116599102453... and ending ...62648323979853562951413.
references: M. Gardner, Whys and Wherefores, Univ. Chicago Press, 1989, p. 84.
N. J. A. Sloane and Simon Plouffe, The Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences, Academic Press, 1995 (includes this sequence).
links: Index entries for sequences related to the number Pi
example: 51413 is in the list because it is prime and its decimal reversal, 31415, is the first 5 digits of Pi.
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_ and _Robert G. Wilson v_
extensions: Edited by _M. F. Hasler_ and _N. J. A. Sloane_, Mar 30 2008
